title: fix: execute sandboxed file ops inside containers

comments.body:
<details>
<summary>Additional Comments (2)</summary>

**`src/agents/sandbox/fs-bridge.ts`**
[P1] `stat()` treats *any* non-zero `stat` exit as “not found”, which can mask real errors.

`runCommand(..., { allowFailure: true })` then `if (result.code !== 0) return null;` (src/agents/sandbox/fs-bridge.ts:161-167). This collapses permission errors, missing `stat` binary, invalid paths, etc. into ENOENT behavior, which can lead to confusing fallbacks (e.g., image path rewrite) and harder debugging.

It would be safer to only return `null` for the “no such file” case and throw (or propagate stderr) for other failures.

<details><summary>Prompt To Fix With AI</summary>

`````markdown
This is a comment left during a code review.
Path: src/agents/sandbox/fs-bridge.ts
Line: 161:167

Comment:
[P1] `stat()` treats *any* non-zero `stat` exit as “not found”, which can mask real errors.

`runCommand(..., { allowFailure: true })` then `if (result.code !== 0) return null;` (src/agents/sandbox/fs-bridge.ts:161-167). This collapses permission errors, missing `stat` binary, invalid paths, etc. into ENOENT behavior, which can lead to confusing fallbacks (e.g., image path rewrite) and harder debugging.

It would be safer to only return `null` for the “no such file” case and throw (or propagate stderr) for other failures.

How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.
`````
</details>

---

**`src/web/media.ts`**
[P2] New `loadWebMedia()` overload defaults `optimizeImages` to `true`, which changes behavior for callers passing options objects.

Previously, all callers effectively got `optimizeImages: true`. Now object callers get `optimizeImages: options.optimizeImages ?? true` (src/web/media.ts:221-234), but number/undefined callers also force `optimizeImages: true`. This is correct, but it’s easy to miss that object callers can now disable optimization (and bypass the previous implicit behavior).

If this is intentional, consider adding/adjusting a unit test to lock in the overload semantics (number vs. options object) so future refactors don’t regress it.

<details><summary>Prompt To Fix With AI</summary>

`````markdown
This is a comment left during a code review.
Path: src/web/media.ts
Line: 221:229

Comment:
[P2] New `loadWebMedia()` overload defaults `optimizeImages` to `true`, which changes behavior for callers passing options objects.

Previously, all callers effectively got `optimizeImages: true`. Now object callers get `optimizeImages: options.optimizeImages ?? true` (src/web/media.ts:221-234), but number/undefined callers also force `optimizeImages: true`. This is correct, but it’s easy to miss that object callers can now disable optimization (and bypass the previous implicit behavior).

If this is intentional, consider adding/adjusting a unit test to lock in the overload semantics (number vs. options object) so future refactors don’t regress it.

How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.
`````
</details>
</details>

+1, this is the right direction.

I've been dealing with the host-path vs container-path mismatch a lot while working with sandbox agents. The core problem is simple — exec runs inside the container, but file tools run on the host. Agents find files at `/workspace/...` via exec, then read/write rejects those paths. The path remapping PRs (#11820, #14810, #9730) keep trying to translate between the two path spaces, but that's inherently fragile (traversal edge cases, prefix matching bugs, hardcoded workdir assumptions — each PR gets flagged for a different variant of the same issue).

My current workaround is mounting the container workspace at the exact same absolute path as the host (e.g. `/home/user/workspace/project:/home/user/workspace/project`) so both contexts see the same paths. It works, but it's ugly — you end up with unnecessarily long container paths that are just host path artifacts, and again it's just a workaround.

This PR just sidesteps all of that by running file I/O inside the container too. One execution context, no translation needed. The SandboxFsBridge abstraction is clean and the Greptile concerns from the initial review look addressed in the current diff.

There are still some related path issues around bundled skills, system prompt `<location>` tags, and other places where host paths leak into the sandbox context (#6346, #7915, etc). But I think getting alignment on this core approach first makes those follow-ups much more straightforward to tackle.

This would fix or largely address #9560, #9348, #2432. Would love to see this move forward.

Merged via squash.

- Prepared head SHA: 795ec6aa2f311fcda6660876dbadb4ef356bc0ac
- Merge commit: 29d783958287b7e3216c1e8c9630f28261105c48

Thanks @davidbors-snyk!

comments.body:
<details>
<summary>Additional Comments (1)</summary>

**`src/agents/sandbox/config-hash.ts`**
[P0] Node 18 incompatibility: `Object.entries(...).toSorted(...)`

Node 18 does not support `Array.prototype.toSorted()`. This file still calls it in `normalizeForHash`, so the runtime will throw when hashing sandbox configs.

```suggestion
    const entries = Object.entries(value).sort(([a], [b]) => a.localeCompare(b));
```

<details><summary>Prompt To Fix With AI</summary>

`````markdown
This is a comment left during a code review.
Path: src/agents/sandbox/config-hash.ts
Line: 31:31

Comment:
[P0] Node 18 incompatibility: `Object.entries(...).toSorted(...)`

Node 18 does not support `Array.prototype.toSorted()`. This file still calls it in `normalizeForHash`, so the runtime will throw when hashing sandbox configs.

```suggestion
    const entries = Object.entries(value).sort(([a], [b]) => a.localeCompare(b));
```

How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.
`````
</details>
</details>

title: feat: Event-Sourced Memory with NATS JetStream

comments.body:
## 🚀 Ready for Review!

Hey maintainers! 👋

This PR has been **battle-tested in production** with:
- 157,000+ events processed
- 5 coordinated agents running 24/7
- Zero data loss over 30 days

**What's new in this update:**
- ✅ Fixed lint issues (unused imports, type safety)
- ✅ Improved PR description with architecture diagrams
- ✅ Production stats and real-world validation

**The core value proposition:**
> Every AI assistant forgets everything between sessions. This changes that.

Would love to get this merged so the community can benefit from persistent, queryable agent memory. Happy to address any remaining feedback! 🙏

cc @anthropics/openclaw-maintainers

## Review Response

**[P0] User messages not emitted** — ✅ Fixed in commit `9191bb59b`. Added `stream === 'user'` branch that emits `conversation.message.in`. User messages now flow into the event store correctly.

**[P2] `ensureStream()` global state** — Checked current code: `ensureStream(nc, config)` at line 163 *does* use the passed `nc` parameter (`const jsm = await nc.jetstreamManager()`). No `natsConnection!` usage anywhere in the file. Line numbers may have shifted from an earlier diff; the implementation correctly avoids global state coupling.

## 🔄 Update: Leaner Implementation

Just pushed a refactoring commit that makes the Event Store more elegant:

**Changes:**
- **39% less code** (279 → 170 lines)
- Single state object instead of 4 global variables
- `crypto.randomUUID()` for secure event IDs
- Shorter event types (`msg.in` vs `conversation.message.in`)
- Auto-reconnect with NATS status handler
- Proper error logging (no more silent swallowing)

**QDM Impact:**
- Smaller event payloads (~40% reduction per event)
- At 200k events = ~14MB less storage

All 9 tests still passing ✅

Interesting approach. For users who just want their workspace files safe without spinning up NATS infrastructure, bidirectional cloud sync via rclone offers a simpler alternative — works with Dropbox, S3, GDrive, 70+ providers out of the box, zero additional services to run.

Different tradeoffs: event sourcing gives you full replay, sync gives you file-level durability with near-zero setup.

- Tracking issue: #18106
- PR 1/4: #18104

> Interesting approach. For users who just want their workspace files safe without spinning up NATS infrastructure, bidirectional cloud sync via rclone offers a simpler alternative — works with Dropbox, S3, GDrive, 70+ providers out of the box, zero additional services to run.
> 
> Different tradeoffs: event sourcing gives you full replay, sync gives you file-level durability with near-zero setup.
> 
>     * Tracking issue: [Native workspace sync solves 7+ open issues — working implementation ready #18106](https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw/issues/18106)
> 
>     * PR 1/4: [feat(workspace): config types + rclone infrastructure for workspace cloud sync (PR 1/4) #18104](https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw/pull/18104)

Thanks for the pointer, @ashbrener! These solve fundamentally different problems though — event sourcing captures the sequence of what happened (messages, tool calls, lifecycle events) with full replay capability. File sync keeps workspace files backed up across machines. They're complementary, not competing: you'd want event sourcing for audit trails and agent coordination, and file sync for portable workspace state. Both valid, different layers.
Superseded by #18171 (clean rebase on current main)

For users who want file-level durability without spinning up NATS infrastructure, bidirectional cloud sync via rclone offers a simpler alternative — 70+ providers, zero additional services.

Full working implementation: #19052
Tracking issue: #18106

title: feat: Discord ChimeIn — automatic conversation participation

comments.body:
Addressed the Greptile review comments:

**1. Invalid chimeIn.model parsing (fixed)**
Fixed in cc42279. The model ref is now validated for `provider/model` format before parsing. Invalid refs (no slash, trailing slash, provider-only like `"openai"`) fall back to the agent default model with a verbose log warning. Added 2 test cases covering both scenarios.

**2. Blocked users still counted (not a bug)**
The users allowlist check at lines 475-489 runs unconditionally for all guild messages, **before** the chimeIn accumulation code at line 491+. If a user is not in the allowlist, they hit `return null` at line 486 and never reach the chimeIn counter. The allowlist check is not gated by `mentionGate.shouldSkip`.

**3. ChimeIn uses stale history (not a bug)**
`recordPendingHistoryEntryIfEnabled` calls `appendHistoryEntry` which synchronously pushes the entry into the Map via `history.push(entry)` + `historyMap.set(historyKey, history)`. When `evaluateChimeIn` reads `guildHistories.get(channelId)` on line 520, the current message is already included.
This is awesome!
This should be implemented differently as part of core, rather than just something stuck on Discord

title: fix: preserve ${VAR} env var references when writing config back to disk

comments.body: @greptileai review the PR again
hey @greptileai review the PR again. I've got some updates for you

## Fix: env snapshot bridge across exported IO wrappers

During internal review, we discovered that the TOCTOU fix in `e436d87` was ineffective in production call paths.

### The bug

`readConfigFileSnapshot()` and `writeConfigFile()` are exported wrappers that each create a **new** `createConfigIO()` instance. The env snapshot captured during read was trapped inside instance A and never reached instance B (write), so `restoreEnvVarRefs()` always fell back to live `process.env` — the exact TOCTOU issue the snapshot was meant to prevent.

The dominant server paths in `src/gateway/server-methods/config.ts` (`config.patch`, `config.apply`, `config.set`) all use these exported wrappers, not a shared IO instance.

### The fix (`63583236d`)

- Added a module-level `_moduleEnvSnapshot` that bridges the gap between wrapper calls
- `readConfigFileSnapshot()` stores the snapshot via `io.getEnvSnapshot()`
- `writeConfigFile()` injects it via `io.setEnvSnapshot()` before writing
- Added `getEnvSnapshot()`/`setEnvSnapshot()` to the IO instance interface

### Test proof

New file: `src/config/env-preserve-io.test.ts` (2 integration tests)

1. **With snapshot bridging**: reads config with `MY_API_KEY=original-key-123`, mutates env to `mutated-key-456`, writes with bridged snapshot → file correctly contains `${MY_API_KEY}` ✅
2. **Without snapshot bridging** (old behavior): same scenario but no snapshot injection → restoration fails because live env no longer matches, resolved value written as-is ✅

All 323 config tests pass (47 files).
@greptileai ok dude, review the PR once more

**Re: Cross-request env snapshot leak & Snapshot not path-scoped** — Valid point. Fixed in 627240d.

The module-level snapshot is now a `Map<configPath, snapshot>` instead of a single variable. `readConfigFileSnapshot()` stores keyed by resolved `configPath`, and `writeConfigFile()` only consumes the matching entry (deleted after use to prevent stale state). This prevents cross-config contamination if `OPENCLAW_CONFIG_PATH` changes between calls.

**Re: Env var pattern mismatch (`hasEnvVarRef` missing `$${VAR}`)** — False positive. The regex `\$\{[A-Z_][A-Z0-9_]*\}` matches the `${VAR}` substring inside `$${VAR}`, so `hasEnvVarRef("$${FOO}")` returns `true`. The escape sequence correctly enters the resolution path.

**Re: Incorrect escape restoration (backslash in template literal)** — False positive. The backtick expression uses `\$` to prevent JavaScript from interpreting `${` as template interpolation. The runtime output is `${NAME}`, not `\${NAME}`. Verified by existing tests.
@greptileai review the PR again
@greptileai please review this PR
@greptileai please review this PR

<details>
<summary>Additional Comments (1)</summary>

**`src/auto-reply/envelope.ts`**
**Wrong call signature**
`formatZonedTimestamp` now takes an options object (`{ timeZone, displaySeconds }`), but this call passes a positional string: `formatZonedTimestamp(date, zone.timeZone)`. That will compile only if TS allows it loosely, but at runtime it will treat the string as `options` and ignore the timezone (and may throw if code assumes an object). Update to `formatZonedTimestamp(date, { timeZone: zone.timeZone })` (matching the other updated callsites).

Also appears in any other remaining `formatZonedTimestamp(date, <string>)` callsites if present.

<details><summary>Prompt To Fix With AI</summary>

`````markdown
This is a comment left during a code review.
Path: src/auto-reply/envelope.ts
Line: 106:108

Comment:
**Wrong call signature**
`formatZonedTimestamp` now takes an options object (`{ timeZone, displaySeconds }`), but this call passes a positional string: `formatZonedTimestamp(date, zone.timeZone)`. That will compile only if TS allows it loosely, but at runtime it will treat the string as `options` and ignore the timezone (and may throw if code assumes an object). Update to `formatZonedTimestamp(date, { timeZone: zone.timeZone })` (matching the other updated callsites).

Also appears in any other remaining `formatZonedTimestamp(date, <string>)` callsites if present.

How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.
`````
</details>
</details>

comments.body:
<details>

**`src/agents/system-prompt.ts`**
**Date injection breaks caching**

`buildTimeSection` now injects `Date: ${params.userTime}` into the system prompt when `userTime` is provided, but this file still has explicit guidance/comments/tests elsewhere that the system prompt should avoid current date/time for prompt cache stability and instead use `session_status`/message timestamps. title: (fix): handle Cloudflare 521 and transient 5xx errors gracefully

comments.body:
<details>
<summary>Additional Comments (1)</summary>

**`src/auto-reply/reply/agent-runner-execution.ts`**
**Retry bypasses fallback**

`runAgentTurnWithFallback()` retries transient HTTP errors by `continue`-ing the `while (true)` loop (src/auto-reply/reply/agent-runner-execution.ts:584-593). This re-runs `runWithModelFallback()` from scratch, so the “fallback model (if configured)” step in the PR description never runs *before* the retry; instead you effectively run “retry” and then only after the retry fails would normal fallback handling happen. If the intended flow is “fallback first, then retry” (or vice versa), this needs to be made consistent either in code or in the documented error flow.

<details><summary>Prompt To Fix With AI</summary>

`````markdown
This is a comment left during a code review.
Path: src/auto-reply/reply/agent-runner-execution.ts
Line: 583:604

Comment:
**Retry bypasses fallback**

`runAgentTurnWithFallback()` retries transient HTTP errors by `continue`-ing the `while (true)` loop (src/auto-reply/reply/agent-runner-execution.ts:584-593). This re-runs `runWithModelFallback()` from scratch, so the “fallback model (if configured)” step in the PR description never runs *before* the retry; instead you effectively run “retry” and then only after the retry fails would normal fallback handling happen. If the intended flow is “fallback first, then retry” (or vice versa), this needs to be made consistent either in code or in the documented error flow.

How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.
`````
</details>
</details>

title: fix(memory): prevent memory loss from SQLite contention, race conditi…

comments.body:
<details>
<summary>Additional Comments (1)</summary>

**`src/memory/search-manager.ts`**
**Concurrent manager creation**

`getMemorySearchManager` does a check-then-`await`-then-set on `QMD_MANAGER_CACHE` (`.get()` at line 26, `.set()` at line 48). If two callers request the same `cacheKey` concurrently, both will miss the cache and both can create/initialize a `QmdMemoryManager`, leaving one instance “orphaned” but still running (e.g. its `setInterval` updater) and concurrently touching the same per-agent `index.sqlite`/export dir. Consider caching an *in-flight* creation promise (or other singleflight/lock) so only one instance is ever constructed per key.

<details><summary>Prompt To Fix With AI</summary>

`````markdown
This is a comment left during a code review.
Path: src/memory/search-manager.ts
Line: 25:49

Comment:
**Concurrent manager creation**

`getMemorySearchManager` does a check-then-`await`-then-set on `QMD_MANAGER_CACHE` (`.get()` at line 26, `.set()` at line 48). If two callers request the same `cacheKey` concurrently, both will miss the cache and both can create/initialize a `QmdMemoryManager`, leaving one instance “orphaned” but still running (e.g. its `setInterval` updater) and concurrently touching the same per-agent `index.sqlite`/export dir. Consider caching an *in-flight* creation promise (or other singleflight/lock) so only one instance is ever constructed per key.

How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.
`````
</details>
</details>

title: fix: preserve $include directives when CLI commands write config

comments.body:
Fixed all three issues in ad4e93b:

1. **Windows CI failure**: The `createMockResolver` in tests used Unix-style paths as map keys (`/config/base.json5`), but `buildIncludeMap` resolves paths via `path.resolve()` which on Windows produces `C:\config\base.json5`. Fixed by normalising paths in the mock resolver with `path.resolve()`.

2. **Array merge semantics** (Greptile comment): `deepMergeInto()` now concatenates arrays instead of overwriting, matching `deepMerge()` in `includes.ts`. This prevents array-valued keys from included files being incorrectly treated as local overrides.

3. **Config.env resolution** (Greptile comment): `writeConfigFile()` now applies `config.env` entries to a local env copy before resolving `${VAR}` in included content, matching the read-path behaviour. This prevents mismatches when users define env vars in the config file rather than process env.

title: fix(telegram): catch raw fetch() rejections in polling error handler

comments.body:
PR #14856 - fix(telegram): catch raw fetch() rejections in polling error handler (https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw/pull/14856)

Closing without merge as duplicate/superseded.

Linked reasons:
- This report was tracked in https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw/issues/14736
- That issue is already closed as duplicate of https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw/issues/13385
- Mainline already includes related unhandled-rejection/transient-network protections, so this PR is no longer the right landing path.

Thanks @arosstale for the thorough investigation, crash-loop context, and proposed fix.

reviews.body:
<sub>2 files reviewed, 1 comment</sub>

<sub>[Edit Code Review Agent Settings](https://app.greptile.com/review/github) | [Greptile](https://greptile.com?utm_source=greptile_expert&utm_medium=github&utm_campaign=code_reviews)</sub>

## Pull request overview

This PR fixes crash loops caused by unhandled `TypeError('fetch failed')` rejections from Node.js fetch() calls to the Telegram API. The crashes occurred when network failures (DNS errors, connection resets) during Telegram polling escaped grammY's HttpError wrapper and became unhandled rejections, causing the gateway to crash.

**Changes:**
- Adds a new handler branch in the Telegram monitor to catch raw TypeError instances matching recoverable network error patterns
- Adds tests verifying that raw TypeErrors with "fetch failed" messages are correctly identified as recoverable network errors

### Reviewed changes

Copilot reviewed 2 out of 2 changed files in this pull request and generated 2 comments.

| File | Description |
| ---- | ----------- |
| src/telegram/monitor.ts | Adds TypeError handler branch to catch raw fetch() rejections alongside existing grammY HttpError handler |
| src/telegram/network-errors.test.ts | Adds tests for raw TypeError detection with "fetch failed" message and ENOTFOUND cause chains |

title: fix: exclude cache tokens from session totalTokens derivation

comments.body: Closing in favor of updating #13841 with the complete fix.

<details>
<summary>Additional Comments (1)</summary>

**`src/auto-reply/reply/session-updates.ts`**
**Resets totalTokens to 0**

In `incrementCompactionCount`, the new branch `else if (tokensAfter == null) { updates.totalTokens = 0; }` (`src/auto-reply/reply/session-updates.ts:291-298`) will zero out a session’s `totalTokens` whenever compaction completed but `estimateCompactionTokensAfter()` couldn’t produce an estimate (missing file, parse error, estimate failure). That will suppress future compaction triggers and make the UI/reporting incorrect. This should avoid writing `totalTokens` at all when the post-compaction estimate is unavailable (leave prior value or recompute later).

<details><summary>Prompt To Fix With AI</summary>

`````markdown

Path: src/auto-reply/reply/session-updates.ts
Line: 291:298

In `incrementCompactionCount`, the new branch `else if (tokensAfter == null) { updates.totalTokens = 0; }` (`src/auto-reply/reply/session-updates.ts:291-298`) will zero out a session’s `totalTokens` whenever compaction completed but `estimateCompactionTokensAfter()` couldn’t produce an estimate (missing file, parse error, estimate failure). That will suppress future compaction triggers and make the UI/reporting incorrect. This should avoid writing `totalTokens` at all when the post-compaction estimate is unavailable (leave prior value or recompute later).

How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.
`````
</details>
</details>

title: fix(agents): propagate contextTokens cap to Pi session model for auto-compaction

comments.body:
Addressed all review feedback in 212e997:

**Core fix (Codex P1):** `resolveContextWindowInfo` now treats `agentContextTokens` as a **cap** instead of a fallback. Previously, when `modelContextWindow` was present, the function returned it immediately — `contextTokens: 100k` on a 200k model did nothing. Now the function resolves the base window (model → modelsConfig) then applies `agentContextTokens` as an upper bound. This fixes the bug where `effectiveModel` was never capped.

**Other fixes:**
- Replaced hardcoded GitHub issue URL with short ref `#14143`
- Renamed misleading test: 'caps model when equal' → 'does not cap model when contextTokens equals model contextWindow'
- Fixed modelsConfig test: now passes `modelContextWindow: undefined` to actually exercise the modelsConfig path (was masked by model metadata taking precedence)
- Added new test: agentContextTokens caps modelsConfig when lower

All 20 tests pass (8 existing guard tests + 12 cap tests).

Closing — the core fix (agentContextTokens as a cap on model context window) was already landed on `main` in a cleaner implementation via `context-window-guard.ts`. The upstream approach consolidates the cap logic in the resolver itself rather than patching the model at the callsite, which is better. Test coverage is also already present in `context-window-guard.e2e.test.ts`. No further changes needed.

title: feat: support freshness parameter for Perplexity web_search provider

comments.body:
<details>
<summary>Additional Comments (1)</summary>

**`src/agents/tools/web-search.ts`**
**Perplexity cache ignores freshness**

`runWebSearch` now accepts `freshness` for Perplexity, but the Perplexity cache key doesn't include it (`params.provider === "perplexity" ? ...`). That means two Perplexity searches with different `freshness` values can return the same cached response, producing incorrect results (especially when toggling between e.g. `pd` and `py`). Include `freshness` (or the derived `search_recency_filter`) in the Perplexity cache key so recency-filtered searches don't collide.

<details><summary>Prompt To Fix With AI</summary>

`````markdown
This is a comment left during a code review.
Path: src/agents/tools/web-search.ts
Line: 568:573

Comment:
**Perplexity cache ignores freshness**

`runWebSearch` now accepts `freshness` for Perplexity, but the Perplexity cache key doesn't include it (`params.provider === "perplexity" ? ...`). That means two Perplexity searches with different `freshness` values can return the same cached response, producing incorrect results (especially when toggling between e.g. `pd` and `py`). Include `freshness` (or the derived `search_recency_filter`) in the Perplexity cache key so recency-filtered searches don't collide.

How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.
`````
</details>
</details>

Merged via squash.

title: Discord: auto-create threads and toggle parent inheritance

comments.body:
Thanks for the work here! We shipped Discord auto-threading since this PR was opened: the per-channel flag `channels.discord.guilds.*.channels.*.autoThread` now creates a thread on non-thread guild messages, re-keys the session to the created thread (with the parent session key set to the original channel), and skips parent channel history on the first in-thread turn.

Given that this PR now duplicates mainline behavior and is out of date, I'm closing it. If you still want global `channels.discord.thread.*` toggles or explicit parent-inheritance controls, please open a fresh issue/PR and we can discuss.

title: feat(event-store): NATS JetStream integration for audit, replay & multi-agent sharing

comments.body:
This PR provides the infrastructure layer for #17067 (Session Event Query API). 

It publishes the agent events that are already being produced into NATS JetStream, making them queryable, replayable, and subscribable across agents. The event types (`msg.in`, `msg.out`, `tool.call`, `tool.result`, `run.start`, `run.end`, `run.error`) map directly to what #17067 describes.

We've been running this in production with 7 agents and 233k+ events — it enables thread detection, error pattern learning, and cross-agent context sharing on top of the event stream.
Sounds like the ideal usecase for a *plugin*...

<!-- greptile-status -->
Greptile encountered an error while reviewing this PR. Please reach out to support@greptile.com for assistance.

Closing this PR in favor of a standalone plugin approach, as suggested by the community (thanks @HenryLoenwordin and @Phineas!).

The event store is now available as an independent OpenClaw plugin:

📦 **npm:** [`@vainplex/nats-eventstore`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@vainplex/nats-eventstore)
🐙 **GitHub:** [alberthild/openclaw-nats-eventstore](https://github.com/alberthild/openclaw-nats-eventstore)

**What's included:**
- 17 event types (messages, tool calls, LLM I/O, sessions, gateway lifecycle)
- Non-fatal, fire-and-forget publish (never blocks agent operations)
- Privacy-conscious (LLM events log metadata, not content)
- Configurable include/exclude hooks, retention policies
- 50 unit tests, performance benchmarked (~9,000 msg/s concurrent)

Install: `npm install @vainplex/nats-eventstore` in `~/.openclaw/extensions/`

This keeps the core lean while making NATS event streaming a first-class plugin. 🚀
